Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaires

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A MODEL OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual will be asked identical questions. Although the same questions may be asked, there may be variations in answers.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Have?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer children and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A MODEL OF QUESTIONNAIRE FOR THE PROJECT

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual will be able to answer all of the questions. Therefore, answers should be given in such a way that they may prove useful to others who may be interested in pioneer experiences. It is not necessary to give detailed or descriptive particulars; if they help to answer the questions, they should be included.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Western Canadian Pioneers: What Did They Do?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Well, I think it interesting to recollect when I took up homesteading a few years ago and found that practically all transactions had to be made by mail. Our stock was purchased even before we arrived at the place. We had to make arrangements to have our land surveyed and to notify the government of our intention to settle there. We had to make sure that we had enough money to purchase our land and to pay our taxes. We also had to make sure that we had enough food and supplies to last us until we could earn a living. It was a difficult time, but we persevered and eventually we were able to establish ourselves on the land.

24. What kind of transportation did you use in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

The only type of transportation we had was horse-drawn. The roads were very rough and travel was slow. It took about 7 hours to travel from 14 to 20 miles. We took advantage of any town we came across and used the church services whenever possible. We also attended church regularly.
